audio_caption: The clip begins with dramatic, suspenseful orchestral music creating a sense of foreboding. Then, a male speaker begins, stating that stepping outside the "accepted academic narrative" will bring "heat," and emphasizes that "something happened, and it was significant." This shifts to a more conversational male voice explaining that they're talking about "truths." They mention being trusted to work at the Pentagon after 9/11 and being assigned by the government to do that work. Finally, a cheerful female voice introduces herself and her companion, welcoming viewers and asking for introductions and the speakers' work. An electronic sound then cuts the end of the clip.
The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing himself as Scott Wolter, a forensic geologist by profession, who also studies Templar history. His tone is relaxed and conversational.

The audio clip begins with a woman asking a question about "12,000 year cycles" from a geological point of view. The tone is conversational and curious. A man responds enthusiastically about the "procession of the equinoxes," noting that it's a 26,000-year cycle, explaining how it relates to the constellations and equinoxes. He's very familiar with the topic. He then asks the woman if she realizes they're in an important time of procession. She confirms, explaining that the earth goes through cycles, noting that there are 12,000 and 24,000-year cycles, which are revealed through ice cores, and that these coincide with disasters. She adds they are currently in one of those cycles and asks if the man knows about this from his studies.

The clip starts with a male speaker acknowledging awareness of a topic, mentioning the Younger Dryas period and Graham Hancock's series "Ancient Apocalypse." The speaker continues in a conversational tone, suggesting Hancock makes a compelling case that there was "a significant ... either a comet, a meteorite, some type of extraterrestrial event," and that it had a "catastrophic" impact on Earth and human cultures. The speaker concludes by stating the event had significant fallout.

The clip starts with a male speaker expressing admiration for someone who asks questions, despite receiving criticism. He states that standing behind the facts is one's foundation. He adds that one should admit when they don't know everything and that more data is needed. He concludes that it is a significant thing, hoping academics will be more open-minded. A female speaker then adds a statement regarding events happening every 12,000 years.

The audio clip features a male speaker responding to the question of whether he has dealt with censorship or shadow banning, such as on YouTube. He begins his response in a serious tone, stating he has been "whitewashed from the internet." He recounts writing a book on a particular subject, but when researching on Wikipedia, you will not find his name or books. He continues by mentioning the next three books were about, then explains that "there's nobody walking the planet right now that knows more about this artifact than me". He explains that none of his research or books are on the Wikipedia site.

A male speaker starts, speaking at a normal pace. He mentions a book written by an academic, Alice Beck Kehoe, and says "a friend of mine, who wrote a book a year after our Kensington Runestone compelling new evidence book was published". The speaker mentions that she wrote about their book, stating, "She said we solved it". He continues, noting it's cited on wiki but not the book she's talking about and then ends by saying, "and I don't think they understand what I do for a living".

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing his work in forensic investigations. He describes his use of the scientific method and contrasts his approach with that of "soft scientists" in the humanities, who, according to him, are critical of his conclusions. The speaker states he is willing to correct mistakes if identified, but he believes their issue is with the result, not the methodology. He concludes with a firm declaration of standing by his position.

The audio begins with a female speaker noting the lack of information when she googled someone and mentions challenges with social media channels being deleted from a creative society. She speaks in a conversational tone. The female speaker continues by questioning the importance of nationalizing Google, expressing concern over a "tyrant that controls everything".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing uncertainty, saying "I don't know what the answer is" but advocating for monitoring and oversight due to dark things happening. His tone is conversational but slightly hesitant. This speech is followed by background sounds hinting at an outdoor environment, and the male speaker resumes talking.

The audio features a single male speaker discussing the importance of respecting everyone's opportunity to have a voice and to present evidence, allowing others to decide if it makes sense. His tone is conversational. This is accompanied by music in the background, it has an ambient quality to it.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a slightly exasperated tone, defending his expertise. He references being "trusted to do the work at the Pentagon after 9/11" and says the government assigned him to that work, implying that he must "know what I'm doing." He talks about working on other projects like "murder cases" and contrasts this with how he is viewed when working on "controversial artifacts," where he feels dismissed as "some moron that doesn't know what he's talking about, some fringe geologist."

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing his opinion and noting some hypocrisy. He emphasizes that discussions should be open and that censorship should be absent. He commits to speaking what he believes to be true and acknowledging the implications, even if some may not approve. The speaker transitions to a more resigned tone, accepting that life doesn't always align with one's wishes. A female voice then interjects with agreement saying "yes."

The audio clip begins with a woman expressing gratitude, saying, "Thank you so much for being with us tonight. We really appreciate it," followed by a man responding with "Thank you," and telling them to "keep up the good work". Both speakers sound polite and appreciative. This is followed by a transition to electronic music, in a style that seems dramatic and intense. This musical segment features a strong, melodic synth lead, creating a mood that is both futuristic and somewhat ominous.
